thread.title: ‘Repeal and replace’ won’t happen, Boehner says - MarketWatch
thread.title_full: ‘Repeal and replace’ won’t happen, Boehner says - MarketWatch

author: Emma Court
title: ‘Repeal and replace’ won’t happen, Boehner says - MarketWatch
text:
When it comes to the promised “repeal and replace” of the Affordable Care Act, former House Speaker John Boehner has eschewed alliteration altogether.
All the R-branded monikers are “happy talk,” he said Thursday at the Healthcare Information and Management Systems Society conference in Orlando, Florida.
“[Congressional Republicans are] going to fix Obamacare — I shouldn’t call it repeal-and-replace, because it’s not going to happen,” he said, according to Politico .
Any change to the existing ACA would likely be limited, Boehner said, since “Republicans never ever agree on health care.”
Read: Health insurers will now have until June to decide if they want to be part of Obamacare
Boehner resigned his post in 2015 for private life, after struggling to lead a fractious Republican caucus. Though he is no longer a member of Congress, his contradiction of establishment Republican promises is notable.
House Republicans released the outline of an ACA replacement last week . The proposal, however, lacks some key details, and President Donald Trump has said he will issue his own replacement plan next month.
See: What is the individual health insurance market and why is everyone so worried about it?
Trump: Health-Law Replacement Plan Coming Soon (1:18) President-elect Donald Trump says repeal and replacement of President Obama's health-care law will be done "essentially simultaneously" –- after his health secretary gets confirmed. Photo: Getty
Today, the federal government matches state spending on Medicaid programs, so funding can change depending on what expenses there are. Republican leadership has proposed instead switching to block grants, which is a fixed amount and would limit federal funding.
But Boehner reportedly said that he didn’t expect fewer patients to be covered, according to Shawn Martin, a conference attendee and senior vice president at the American Academy of Family Physicians, in a comment on Twitter.
Humana Inc. HUM, -0.18% said earlier this month that it will exit ACA exchanges by the start of next year. The announcement follows exits by Aetna Inc. AET, +0.59% and UnitedHealth Group Inc. UNH, +0.92%
Anthem Inc. ANTM, +0.49% Centene Corp. CNC, +0.30% and Molina Healthcare MOH, +0.06% have not made any such announcements.
